channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: United Nations Memo: After Orlando, Gay Rights Moves off Diplomatic Back Burner
item.media:description: Members of the gay community and other groups in Bangalore, India, held a demonstration Tuesday to condemn the mass shooting at a gay nightclub in Orlando, Fla.
item.description: The attack on a gay nightclub, and intense lobbying by the United States, jolted opinions on a subject long burdened with cultural sensitivities.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: Killing Twice for ISIS and Saying So Live on Facebook
item.media:description: Police officers at the crime scene a day after a knife-wielding attacker stabbed a police captain in Magnanville, France, on Tuesday.
item.description: Larossi Abballa, who stabbed a police captain and his companion to death, was released almost immediately after his conviction in 2013.
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN and LILIA BLAISE
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Employee of Panama Papers Law Firm, Mossack Fonseca, Is Arrested in Switzerland
item.media:description: The building that houses the Mossack Fonseca law firm offices in Panama City.
item.description: The man was arrested after the firm filed a complaint, but it was not clear if the arrest was connected to the leaked documents that have led to investigations of globally prominent figures.
item.dc:creator: NICK CUMMING-BRUCE and ERIC LIPTON

item.title: Prince William Appears on the Cover of Attitude, a Gay Magazine
item.media:description: Prince William on the cover of Attitude magazine’s July issue.
item.description: The Duke of Cambridge’s cover photo shows a brand of activism that is reminiscent of his mother, Princess Diana.
item.dc:creator: KATIE ROGERS

item.title: Oscar Pistorius Removes His Artificial Legs at Sentencing Hearing
item.description: Mr. Pistorius’s lawyers were trying to highlight the sense of vulnerability they say he felt when, acting out of fear and confusion, he fatally shot his girlfriend.
item.dc:creator: SEWELL CHAN

item.title: Reeva Steenkamp’s Father Says Oscar Pistorius Must Pay for Her Murder
item.media:description: Oscar Pistorius listened as the father of his girlfriend, whom Mr. Pistorius was convicted of murdering, testified in court in Pretoria, South Africa, on Tuesday.
item.description: Barry Steenkamp emphasized that he and his wife had forgiven the South African track star for the shooting, but said the athlete should still face punishment.
item.dc:creator: SEWELL CHAN

item.title: Not Just a U.S. Problem: Black Lives Matter Here, Too, Canadians Say
item.media:description: Black Lives Matter Toronto activists at a protest in April outside the Indigenous and Northern Affairs Canada office in Toronto.
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.description: A growing protest movement in Toronto, fueled by several police shootings of black men, has laid bare the frustrations of black residents.
item.dc:creator: DAN LEVIN

item.title: Worker at Panama Papers Firm Detained, Le Temps Newspaper Says
item.description: A computer technician at the Geneva office of the law firm, Mossack Fonseca, was detained on suspicion of removing large amounts of data, Le Temps reported.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: Searchers Report Finding Egyptair Wreckage
item.description: A search vessel in the Mediterranean found “several main locations of the wreckage” of Flight 804, the Egyptian government said.
item.dc:creator: NICOLA CLARK and RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Amman Journal: Finding Refuge in Jordan, and Adding to Its Cultural Mix
item.media:description: Omar Awad, a marble artist from Damascus, Syria, decamped to Amman, Jordan, four years ago to escape the civil war at home. Instead of designing the marble accents for mansions back home, he now arranges treats in a sweet shop in Amman.
item.media:credit: Tara Todras-Whitehill for The New York Times
item.description: Jordan has absorbed successive waves of people fleeing war and chaos. Some Jordanians blame the newcomers for unwanted changes; others say they have made Amman better.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA and RANA F. SWEIS

item.title: To Secure Loans, Chinese Women Supply Perilous Collateral: Nude Photos
item.description: Women are sending photos of themselves to peer-to-peer lenders, who then sometimes blackmail them when they cannot pay high interest rates, Chinese state media reported.
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW

item.title: Indonesian Doctors’ Group Rejects Decree on Chemical Castration
item.media:description: President Joko Widodo of Indonesia abruptly announced in May that he had signed a decree authorizing chemical castration as well doubling sentences and even permitting the death penalty for sexual assaults on children.
item.description: The decree, by President Joko Widodo, is meant to punish convicted child molesters, but the national medical association says it prefers longer prison sentences.
item.dc:creator: JOE COCHRANE

item.title: A ‘Brexit’ Battle on the Thames
item.media:description: A flotilla of fishing vessels campaigning to leave the European Union sailed up the Thames in London on Wednesday.
item.description: The question of whether Britain should remain in the European Union devolved into a naval confrontation in London on Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: RUSSELL GOLDMAN

item.title: Belgium Warns of Possible Attacks by Militants Traveling From Syria, Report Says
item.media:description: Soldiers on patrol in the northern French city of Lille on Wednesday.
item.description: A communiqué leaked to the news media described extremists leaving the war-torn country to carry out terrorist acts in France and Belgium.
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN

item.title: India Sentences Man-Eating Lion to Life — in the Zoo
item.media:description: An Asiatic lion at the Gir sanctuary in the state of Gujarat, India. It is rare for lions to attack humans, but in the first six months of this year, there have been six killings in the area around the Gir Forest, which is home to India’s only population of wild lions.
item.description: Lion attacks on humans are rare, but in the first six months of this year there have been six killings in the western state of Gujarat.
item.dc:creator: HARI KUMAR

item.title: Wife and Son of China’s Ex-Security Chief Sentenced for Taking Bribes
item.media:description: Zhou Yongkang in 2012. He is currently serving life in prison for corruption and leaking state secrets.
item.description: Jia Xiaoye, whose husband, Zhou Yongkang, was until 2012 one of China’s most powerful officials, received a nine-year term. His son by a previous marriage, Zhou Bin, received 18 years.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE

item.title: Obama and Dalai Lama Meet Over China’s Objection
item.media:description: The Dalai Lama after giving a public talk at Bender Arena at American University in Washington on Monday.
item.description: A Chinese official warned that a meeting between the American president and the exiled Tibetan spiritual leader would “undermine mutual trust and cooperation” between the two countries.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Worries Flare Over Yang Maodong, Jailed Chinese Dissident on Hunger Strike
item.media:description: Yang Maodong, better known by his pen name, Guo Feixiong, at a detention center in Guangzhou, China, in 2014.
item.description: For more than a month, Mr. Yang has resisted eating to protest his conditions in prison and to demand sweeping political change, his family said.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Australian Businessman, Sentenced in China, Gets Early Release Back Home
item.media:description: Matthew Ng had been sentenced by a Chinese court in 2011 to more than 12 years in prison on bribery and fraud charges.
item.description: Matthew Ng, convicted of bribery and fraud charges, had been returned to Sydney under a prisoner exchange treaty.
item.dc:creator: MICHELLE INNIS

item.title: Sinosphere: How the Cultural Revolution Sowed the Seeds of Dissent in China
item.media:description: Red Guards waving copies of Mao Zedong’s “Little Red Book” as they paraded through Beijing in late 1966.
item.description: The sociologist Guobin Yang explains how the turmoil of those years paved the way for the political debates and artistic experiments that followed Mao Zedong’s death.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Tokyo Governor, Yoichi Masuzoe, Resigns Over Spending Scandal
item.description: Mr. Masuzoe, who will step down on Tuesday, is the second governor of the city to quit over a financial scandal in two and a half years.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN SOBLE

item.title: The Interpreter: Control and Fear: What Mass Killings and Domestic Violence Have in Common
item.media:description: Sitora Yusufiy, the ex-wife of the gunman in the nightclub massacre in Orlando, Fla., and her fiancé, Marcio Dias, at their home outside Boulder, Colo., on Sunday.
item.media:credit: Autumn Parry/Daily Camera, via Associated Press
item.description: Research by social scientists reveals striking parallels between what drives the two violent phenomena.
item.dc:creator: AMANDA TAUB

item.title: Leaving Past Behind, Northern Ireland Unified Behind Its Team
item.media:description: Northern Ireland fans applauded their team after Sunday’s loss in the European Championships.
item.description: A boy who watched the biggest soccer match in his country’s history in 1982 is now the coach. He hopes to replicate the team’s success in the European Championships.
item.dc:creator: JAMES MONTAGUE

item.title: Letter From Europe: As ‘Brexit’ Vote Looms, Lessons From Europe’s Battlefields
item.media:description: Michael St Maur Sheil’s photographs show the battlefields of World War I as they are today.
item.description: The same continent that witnessed two world wars over the past century is preparing for a single day that might unravel what many see as its greatest accomplishment.
item.dc:creator: ALAN COWELL

item.title: Orlando Shooting: How the World Is Paying Tribute to the Victims
item.media:description: A mourner had his face painted in rainbow colors in Manila on Tuesday.
item.description: With songs and colored lights, people from Los Angeles to France gathered in a show of solidarity with those killed by Omar Mateen at a gay nightclub in Florida.
item.dc:creator: CHRISTOPHER MELE

item.title: Iran Said to Have Deal With Boeing to Buy Passenger Planes
item.media:description: A Boeing 777 being assembled in Seattle last year.
item.media:credit: Tegra Stone Nuess for The New York Times
item.description: Such an agreement, if completed, would amount to the most prominent commercial transaction between an American company and Iran since antinuclear sanctions were lifted six months ago.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: MSCI Delays Adding China Stock to Emerging Markets Benchmark
item.media:description: Investors looked at stock information at a Shanghai brokerage last month. The government’s grip has tightened after a market crash.
item.description: The index provider’s decision to once again postpone the inclusion of mainland stocks in its influential benchmark reflected continuing concerns over Chinese government intervention.
item.dc:creator: NEIL GOUGH and LANDON THOMAS Jr.

item.title: Russian Diplomat Is Accused of Threatening Rights Activist on Twitter
item.description: The diplomat has been accused of sending a violent message during a United Nations Human Rights Council discussion on protecting rights defenders.
item.dc:creator: NICK CUMMING-BRUCE
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Sichuan Cuisine, Imperiled by Success
item.description: In Chengdu, the capital of Sichuan Province, the region’s famed cuisine is more popular than ever. But traditionalists worry it’s drowning in spice.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Sadiq Khan, New London Mayor, Bans Ads Promoting Unhealthy Body Image
item.media:description: Sadiq Khan, the mayor of London, wants to ban from the city’s public transportation system ads that promote unhealthy or unrealistic body images.
item.media:credit: Yui Mok/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.description: Mr. Khan said he wanted to send a “clear message” to the advertising industry with the new guidelines, which will take effect next month.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Britain’s Top Tabloid, The Sun, Urges Exit From European Union
item.media:description: The front page of The Sun on Tuesday urged readers to vote against European Union membership in the June 23 referendum.
item.description: The Sun endorsed leaving the bloc in a June 23 vote, just as a series of polls suggested support for a “Brexit” was picking up steam.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Orthodox Churches’ Council, Centuries in Making, Falters as Russia Exits
item.media:description: Patriarch Kirill, center, at a liturgy in Karyes, Greece, in May. The Russian Orthodox Church has increasingly sought to assert itself as the pre-eminent voice of the Orthodox faith.
item.description: The Moscow Patriarchate’s decision highlighted tensions between the Russian branch and a rival leadership based in Istanbul.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW HIGGINS

item.title: Terekeka Journal: Dispute Over Area’s Status Heightens Suffering in South Sudan
item.media:description: A family of farmers in Terekeka, South Sudan, said the cost of living had increased as a result of the country’s civil war, which killed tens of thousands of people and displaced more than two million.
item.description: A fragile peace deal could bring traders back to Terekeka after South Sudan’s civil war. But first, the formerly warring parties must agree on what Terekeka is: a county or a state.
item.dc:creator: JACEY FORTIN

item.title: Australian Rodent Is First Mammal Made Extinct by Human-Driven Climate Change, Scientists Say
item.media:description: The Bramble Cay melomys (Melomys rubicola) in Bramble Cay, a tiny outcrop in the Great Barrier Reef, in 2002.
item.media:credit: Ian Bell/Queensland Department of Environment and Heritage Protection
item.description: In 2014, researchers used traps and cameras to try to determine how many Bramble Cay melomys were left on a tiny outcrop in the Great Barrier Reef. They found none.
item.dc:creator: MICHELLE INNIS

item.title: Smithsonian to Open London Exhibition Space With Victoria and Albert Museum
item.description: The American institution’s first permanent outpost abroad will be part of a complex in the east of the city called Olympicopolis, to open in 2021.
item.dc:creator: ROSLYN SULCAS

item.title: Sinosphere: Incendiary Memoir by Chinese Rights Lawyer Reaches Bookshelves Abroad
item.media:description: Grace Geng, the daughter of the human rights lawyer Gao Zhisheng, presented her father’s book, whose Chinese title translates to “The Year 2017, Stand Up, China,” in Hong Kong on Tuesday.
item.description: In the book, the lawyer, Gao Zhisheng, describes his time as a prisoner from 2009 to 2014, when he was released and sent to live under police surveillance.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Philippines Confirms Killing of Robert Hall, Canadian Hostage, by Abu Sayyaf
item.media:description: Robert Hall of Canada in a still image taken from an undated militant video.
item.description: Mr. Hall was abducted by the militant group in September with three other people, one of whom, another Canadian, was killed in April.
item.dc:creator: FLOYD WHALEY and IAN AUSTEN

item.title: China Rules: How China Won the Keys to Disney’s Magic Kingdom
item.media:description: Visitors peeked through the park gates in the run-up to the opening.
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.description: Plans for the $5.5 billion Shanghai Disney Resort, which opens Thursday, were in limbo until Disney dialed back its demands to the Communist Party.
item.dc:creator: DAVID BARBOZA and BROOKS BARNES

item.title: The Interpreter: Gays, Guns and Jihad: Motives Blur on Closer Scrutiny
item.media:description: F.B.I. agents investigating near the damaged rear wall of Pulse, the nightclub in Orlando, Fla., where a gunman carried out a shooting rampage early Sunday.
item.description: By shoehorning attacks like the Orlando rampage into familiar narratives, we think we can make sense of them. But the debate is always unsettled — and always raging.
item.dc:creator: MAX FISHER

item.title: Reports Tell of a Trail of Migrant Deaths Across Deserts and Seas
item.media:description: Crew members of the Norwegian tanker Clipper Hebe moving a coffin containing the body of a migrant at the port of Augusta in Sicily this month. A report released on Tuesday said that thousands of migrants had died trying to cross seas and deserts.
item.description: Millions of migrants have fled war and poverty in their homelands. But two reports on Tuesday highlighted the perils they face as they seek refuge in other countries.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Sinosphere: Taiwan Bars Ex-President From Visiting Hong Kong
item.media:description: Ma Ying-jeou, president of Taiwan at the time, during a visit to Guatemala in March. His trips are largely limited to the 22 countries that recognize Taiwan.
item.description: Travel by the former president, Ma Ying-jeou, was restricted partly because of his previous access to classified information, a government spokesman said.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: What in the World: The Deeper Meaning of Mexico’s Giant Speed Bumps
item.media:description: A well-worn tope in Mexico City, scarred by the undercarriages of countless cars.
item.media:credit: Adriana Zehbrauskas for The New York Times
item.description: Suspension-killing wonders called topes, which crop up on highways and back streets alike, are a means of enforcing speed control and civility, and cannot be avoided.
item.dc:creator: DAMIEN CAVE

item.title: What in the World: Australia’s Answer to Invasive Carp: Unprotected Group Sex (For the Fish)
item.media:credit: Illustration by Tamara Shopsin; photograph by Thinglass/Shutterstock
item.description: European carp are muddying rivers and crowding out native fish Down Under. So scientists hope to control their numbers using a strain of herpes.
item.dc:creator: MICHELLE INNIS

item.title: What in the World: China’s Call to Young Men: Your Nation Needs Your Sperm
item.description: With sperm banks facing shortages, a government campaign tries to overcome cultural barriers to donation with appeals to patriotism (and some cash).
item.dc:creator: JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: The Saint and the Skyscraper
item.description: Can Karachi's savior be saved from property developers?
item.dc:creator: MOHAMMED HANIF

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: Orlando and Trump’s America
item.media:description: Investigators outside the Pulse nightclub in Orlando, Fla., on Sunday.
item.description: Omar Mateen has set a spark to a time of inflammable anger.
item.dc:creator: ROGER COHEN
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Editorial: A Deepening Partnership With India
item.media:description: President Obama and Prime Minister Modi of India at the White House last week.
item.description: Relations with the United States, testy during the Cold War, have warmed over decades and now are producing solid gains under President Obama.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD

item.title: Q. and A.: Ramadan Is Here. What Islam’s Holiest Month Is About.
item.media:description: Muslims praying Sunday in Bali, Indonesia, on the eve of Ramadan.
item.description: A professor who specializes in Islamic studies and Middle Eastern history explains the practices and meaning of Ramadan.
item.dc:creator: BRYANT ROUSSEAU

item.title: Money, Jobs and Sovereignty: Myth vs. Reality Ahead of ‘Brexit’ Vote
item.media:description: Boris Johnson, the former mayor of London, during the Brexit Battle Bus tour in York, England, in May.
item.description: As Britain prepares to vote on June 23 on European Union membership, both sides of the debate warn of dangerous outcomes. We debunk, or back up, their claims.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Not Forgotten: Inside The Times Archives
item.description: Since 1851, more than 200,000 people have been the subjects of obituaries in The New York Times. Join us each day this summer as we revisit many of these memorable lives.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Alissa Rubin, 2016 Pulitzer Winner, Reports From the Front Lines
item.media:description: Alissa Rubin
item.description: Ms. Rubin has spent much of her career covering Iraq, Afghanistan and the Balkans.
item.dc:creator: MIKE McPHATE

item.title: Lens Blog: Photography Pulitzer for Coverage of Refugee Crisis
item.description: The New York Times and Thomson Reuters shared the Pulitzer Prize for breaking news photography for coverage of Europe’s refugee crisis. Jessica Rinaldi of the Boston Globe won the feature photography prize for her story of a boy who endured abuse at the hands of those he trusted.
item.dc:creator: DAVID GONZALEZ and JAMES ESTRIN
